
\lexeme knq
\ph kAn2
\hm 1
\pos n
\sense 1
\definition a shoulder pole, a pole for carrying things on the shoulder by suspending both end
\gloss shoulder pole
\pl knqhpqxW
\pd kAn2 hAp1 khau3
\pde a kind of shoulder pole with both side end pointed used for carrying sheaves of paddy
\example_phake knqhpq
\example_banchob kAn2 hAp1
\example_english a shoulder pole
\se mjknq
\ph mai4 kAn2
\pos n
\definition a pole or stick for carrying things on the shoulder
\gloss pole
\se knqkogq
\ph kAn2 kqN2
\pos n.
\definition a pole for susprnding drum
\gloss pole for susprnding drum
\se knqsF
\ph kAn2 sem3
\pos n.
\definition a bamboo pole with pointed at both ends used for carrying sheave of paddy hanging both end
\gloss pointed pole
\se knqhpqxW
\ph kAn2 hAp1 khau3
\pos n.
\definition a bamboo pole with pointed at both ends used for carrying sheave of paddy hanging both end
\gloss pointed pole
\sense 2
\se knq
\ph kAn2
\pos n.
\definition a beam, a long piece of timber or metal used as a support
\gloss timber used as a support
\pl knqxoukqmogq
\pd kAn2 khok3 mauN2
\pde a beam of a foot morter use for raising the pestle attached while pounding rice
\example_phake knqtJtq
\example_banchob kAn2 tvt1
\example_english a shaft to pull
\se knqvj
\ph kAn2 thai6
\pos n.
\definition beam of a plough
\gloss beam of a plough

\ph kAp1 koi3

\gloss sheath of a banana tree
\se kpqpIkouNq
\ph kAp1 pI2 koi3
\pos n.
\definition a sheath of a banana spadix
\gloss sheath of a banana spadix
\se kpqenamjsgq
\ph kAp1 nq1 mj4 sAN2
\pos .n.
\definition the outer sheath attached to the node of young bamboo joint, or an overlapping protective layer of a bamboo shoot
that are covered with stinging hairs which itchy and irritating if it be touched ( photo )
\gloss outer sheath. young bamboo joint
\se kpqpaelamuwq
\ph kAp1 pa1 lq6 mo1
\pos .n.
\definition the layers of an onion
\gloss layers of onion
\sense 2
\se kpq
\ph kAp1
\pos clf.

\gloss CLF- over lapping layer
\pl kpqko uNqkpqnJgq
\pd kAp1 koi3 kAp1 nvN5
\pde an overlapping protective layer of plantain tree

\pd sz3 kap3

\sense 2
\se kpq
\ph kap3
\pos adj.

\pd ot1 hav3 kap4 ot1
\pde to cork tightly or firmly
\se kpqhI$
\le kpqkpqhIhI
\ph kap3 kap3 hI1 hI1
\pos epress

\gloss magnificently well tight
\sense 3
\se kpq
\ph kap3
\pos .adj.
\definition tight, compact, closely packed together
\gloss tight
\pl tY ikqkpq
\pd taik3 kap3
\pde a tight suitcase i.e. things closely packed together in the suit case
\sense 4
\se kpq
\ph kap3
\pos adj.

\gloss leaving little empty space

\pd kap3 ip4

\ph kap4 kap3 hip1 hip1
\pos express

\gloss allow little room for movement
\pl xokqnjkpDhipD
\pd khauk4 nai4 qn1 phju6 kap3 kap4 hip1 hip1
\pde it was a tight squeeze in this tiny room
\sense 5
\se kpq
\ph kap3
\pos adj.

\sense 6
\se kpq
\ph kap3
\pos adj.
\definition ( of stomach ) flatulent, suffering from a build up of gas in the intestine or stomach
\gloss unease
\pl togqkpq
\pd tauN kap3
\pde trivial complaint of grumble in the stomach, caused by wind
from a build up of gas in the intestine or stomach

\lexeme kupq

\gloss big split piece
\pl fakupq
\pd phA1 kup1
\pde to hew in to a big split piece

\example_banchob mai4 kup1 loN6
\example_english a big split wood
\sense 2
\se kupq
\ph kup1
\pos n

\gloss CLF-wood
\pl gkqmjhEpinqsogqkupq
\pd NAk3 mai4 hav3 pen2 sauN6 kup1
\pde to crack open a piece of wood in to two pieces
\example_phake mjsogqkupq
\example_banchob mai4 sauN6 kup1

\gloss pipe

\example_banchob kauN3 nam4
\example_english a water pipe

\pos n.

\gloss gun

\pd wan2 kam2

people in the honour of < cau3 sz6 > ( ancestor spirit who
looks after the Tai Phake village and the people ) in every after eight days as caculated by them, nobody works before 11a.m
on that day

\lexeme xonq

\lexeme xonq
\ph khqn6
\hm 1
\pos n.
\sense 1
\definition soul, spirit, morale, spiritual element attach to a person,
according to the Tai Phake manuscript of < lik4 hauN4
khqn6 > Book of calling < khqn6 > there are many as 120
< khqns > attach to a person, the Tai Phake belief if the soul
is left it make a person feel physicaly and mentally weak, ill or
 discomfort or shocked into a daze
\gloss morale
\pl xonqtoukq
\pd khqn6 tok1
\pde the soul left the body, because of fright,  ( accoprding to Tai
Phake belief )  the ritual of calling back the separated soul,
by invocation
\example_phake hogqxonqpnqxonq
\example_banchob hauN4 khqn6 pan2 khqn6
\example_english the ceremony of calling back the separated soul, by invocations
\se hikqxonq
\ph hik4 khqn6
\pos v.
\definition calling back the separated < khqn6 >
\gloss calling back separated < khon6 >
\example_phake xonqpj
\example_banchob khqn6 pAi5
\example_english the soul attached is frightened and left away as by shocked
and feel disoriented

\lexeme gokq
\ph Nauk4
\hm 1
\pos v.
\sense 1
\definition nod, to lower and raise one's head briefly to show agreement as greeting or signal
\gloss nod
\pl gokqhuwq
\pd Nauk4 ho6
\pde to nod down the head
\dt 23/Apr/2014

\lexeme gokq

\hm 1
\pos n.

\gloss curved

\gloss curved and stretch

\pde to be tired of waiting
\se gokqgJnqgokqgJnq
\ph Nauk4 NZn2 Nauk4 Nzn2
\pos v.

\gloss curved and stretch

\lexeme cM
\ph cAm5
\hm 1
\pos n
\sense 1
\definition a square fishing net, its four corners are attached to the
four ends of two cross bamboo-sticks. At the cross
centre there is a long pole for suspending. while fishing, the
net is dipped into the water by means of this pole and the net is stretched nearly flat on the
bottom.
\gloss a square fishing net
\se cMkougq
\ph cam5 koN2
\pos n.
\definition a dip net, frame net, fishing net, a kind of fishing
implement made by a square net.  Its four corners are
attached to the four ends of two cross bamboo-sticks
frame at the cross centre, and the net is stretched nearly flat
on the bottom.  there is a  long pole for suspending. while
fishing, the net is  dipped into the water by means of this pole.
\gloss dip net
\se cMvuwq
\ph cam4 tho2
\pos n.

\gloss a kind of net

\se cWsJwq
\ph cau3 sv6
\pos n.
\definition the name of the image of
principal spririt of the Tai
Phake. It is believed as a
guardian spirit and the
protector of the forest, river,
paddy field, as well as  the
society and animals that the
spirit looks after the Tai phake
villages and the Tai Phake
people. Ho Phi ( spirit house )
is usually located in the east of
the village hidden in the forest.
The spirit house in the early
days was humbly built with
bamboo or wood and
thatched roof but now a days
roof with tin and built on
concrete.    The Phakes
worship Chow Shuo and
observed two abstinenance
day  every after eight days
called  <wAn2 kam2 > in
honour of the deity. They
sincerely refrain from tilling
soiling , seedling paddy,
cutting tree, digging soil, and
avoiding making of high
decible sound in the morning
hours in these two days of  <
wan kam > and offer oblation
or perform ritual twice in a
year which falls on the second
day of first wan kam fall in the
month of  < nuon howk >,
and  <nuon sipsong > for the
purpose of good crop, the
well being of the people and
animals and thanks the spirit
for guarding the people.
\gloss spirit
\se cWsJwqmJgq
\ph cau3 sz6 mvN2
\pos n.

principal spririt of the Tai
Phake. It is believed as a

\pos n.
\sense 1
\definition the ancestor spirit and the Tai Phakes belief to be a tutelary spirit who looks  after the
Tai phake villages and the Tai Phake
people. The Phakes worship Chow
Shuo and  observed two abstinenance
day  every after eight days called
<waan2 kam2 > in honour of the deity.
They sincerely refrain from tilling
soiling , seedling paddy, cutting tree,
digging soil, and avoiding making of
high decible sound in the morning hours
in these two days of  < wan kam > and
offer oblation twice in a year which
falls on the second day of first wan
kam fall in the month of  < nuon howk
>, and  <nuon sipsong >
\gloss an ancestor spirit

\lexeme cJmq
\ph czm5
\hm 1
\pos v.
\sense 1
\definition to dissolve, as salt or sugar in damp weather
\gloss dissolve
\pl kJwqcJmq
\pd kz2 czm5
\pde salt dissolve
\sense 2
\se cJmq
\ph czm5
\pos adj.
\definition ( of species or other large group ) extinct, having no living member or no longer existence
\gloss extinct
\pl cJmqhj
\pd czm5 hAi6
\pde become extinct, die out
\example_phake cJmqmoutqka
\example_banchob czm5 mot1 kA1
\example_english completely extinct, die out
\sense 3
\se cJmq
\ph czm5
\pos v.
\definition ( of disease ) to extirpate, eradicate, eliminate, to remove and destroy completely
\gloss extirpate
\example_phake AananWmIcJmqka
\example_banchob a1 nA1 nau6 mI6 czm5 kA1
\example_english the Malaria is said to be eradicated
\sense 4
\se cJmq
\ph czm5
\pos n.
\definition perish, figuratively to be completely destroyed or ruin
\gloss destroy
\pl fjmjcJmq
\pd phaI2 mai3 hzn2 czm5 mot1
\pde to burn to ashes, gutted in to fire
\example_phake cJmqmoutqka
\example_banchob czm5 mot1 kA1
\example_english completely perish away

\le tY igq
\ph taiN1
\hm 1
\pos v.
\sense 1
\definition prepare
\gloss prepare

\example_banchob tq5 nI2 sau2 yeN2   muN5 teu1 pI2 taiN1  wai4
\example_english Then stay looking throughout the whole year, preparing to pray

\lexeme tinq
\ph tIn2
\hm 1
\pos n
\sense 1
\definition foot, leg, each of the limb on which a person or animal moves and stands
\gloss leg
\pl tinqguwq
\pd tin2 No2
\pde leg of a cow
\example_phake tinqkunq
\example_banchob tin2 kon2
\example_english leg of a person
\pl tinqnY iwq
\pd tin2 neu2
\pde uniped, refers to a person or creature with only one foot
\example_phake tinqsogqxonq
\example_banchob tin2 sauN6 khqn1
\example_english biped, refers to a person or creature with only two leg
\sense 2
\se tinq
\ph tIn2
\pos n
\definition a leg, a long thin support or prop or a stand esp. a of chair, a table, tripod, basket etc
\gloss foot
\pl tinqkY igq
\pd tin2 kEN2
\pde leg of a tripod
\example_phake tinqkU
\example_banchob tin2 kU1
\example_english leg of a bedstead
\se tinqsapikq
\ph tIn2 sa1 pik3
\pos n.
\definition stand of monk's rice alm bowl
\gloss stand
\se tinqtgqkkq
\ph tin2 taN1 kAk3
\pos n.
\definition leg of a chair
\gloss leg
\sense 3
\se tinq
\ph tIn2
\pos n.
\definition the bottom of something vertical
\gloss stand
\pl tinqnoj
\pd tIn2 nqi2
\pde foothill, a low hill at the base of a mountain
\example_phake tinqsW
\example_banchob tin2 sau6
\example_english foot of a post, bottom of a piller
\sense 4
\se tinq
\ph tin2
\pos n.
\definition hemline, the level of the lower part of a garment such as a woman's lower garment skirt
\gloss hemline
\pl tinqsinq
\pd tin2 sin3
\pde the hemline of a woman's lower germent < sin 3> or the bottom part from knee
downward of a < sin3 >

\lexeme tI
\ph tI5
\hm 1
\pos adv
\sense 1
\definition at, on, to, in
\gloss at
\pl tIninq
\pd tI5 nin2
\pde at the ground, on the ground
\example_phake xMtIlikq
\example_banchob kham1 tI5 lik4
\example_english to read hard ( at the book )
\pl cJwqfjtIvJnq
\pd cv3 phai2 tI5 thzn1
\pde to set the forest on fire
\example_phake tkqfatIfunq
\example_banchob tAk1 phA3 tI5 phon6
\example_english to expose cloth to the rain
\se lukqestIpJnq
\ph luk4 se6 tI5 pzn5
\definition from other, lit. from at other
\gloss from other
\example_phake ygqtIvugq
\example_banchob yaN2 tI5 thiN6
\example_english having in the bag
\se tIxunqtgq
\ph tI4 khun6 tAN2
\definition ( while travelling ) on the way
\gloss on the way
\pl hWhupqwjtIxunqtgq
\pd haN2 mvn2 hau2 hop4 wai4 tI4 khun6 tAN2
\pde we met him on the way
\example_phake tImJgqhImJgqhM

\se tjfaekmJgqAasM
\ph tai phake mzN2 a1 sam1
\definition The Tai Phakes  is a branch of
great Tai race and Buddhist
population of Assam, India
with its microscopic existence,
less than 2000 souls are mostly
dwelt in villages. The Tai
Phakes had migrated from
Moung Mao  of South China,
across Myanmar and then Pat
Kai Hills and finally entered
Assam through Pang Shau
Pass in 1775 AD and
embraces the Brahmaputra
valley as their home. ( add ailot )

\gloss type . plant ( photo )

\dn তৰুৱা কদম
\dt 30/Mar/2015

\lexeme ngqwtq
\ph nAN1 wAt4
\hm 1
\pos n
\sense 1
\definition a kind of quite wide and long cloth,  used by Tai Phake women to wrap around the
chest. The married girls use <banchob  nAN1 wAt4 lAi2> - a <banchob nAN1 wAt4>
 with colourful stripes, but the unmarried  girls use the white ones called <banchob
lAN1 wAt4 phzk1> (also <banchob lAN1  wAt4>).
\gloss clothing.type
\pl hgqngqwtq
\pd haN4 nAN1 wAt3
\pde to wrap or to drape  a long cloth  around the chest
exteded to buttock to cover the breast use as Tai Phake  married  woman traditional dress
\dt 06/Jun/2014

\hm 1
\pos adj.
\sense 1
\definition without, bare, not accompanied by or having the use of, not wearing or without the proper
or usual covering or content as cloth,  shoe etc
\gloss bare
\pl AUtuwqnj
\pd U1 to2 nAi2
\pde to be in bare body, body without clothing
\example_phake pjtinqnj
\example_banchob pai2 tin2 nAi2
\example_english to walk in bare foot
\se tuwqnj
\ph tO2 nAi2
\pos n
\definition indecent exposure, bare body, body without clothing
\gloss body without clothing,
\se mJwqnj
\ph mv2 nai2
\pos adj.
\definition empty-handed, without tools, weapons or anything
\gloss empty-handed
\se pokqmJwqnj
\ph pauk1 mz2 nAi2
\definition to come back or return  home without anything
\gloss come back home without anything,

\lexeme nM
\ph nAm1
\hm 1
\pos n'
\sense 1
\definition the day of the week on which one is born. Each day is represented by an animal;
as Sunday is Garuda, Monday-Tiger, Tuesday-Lion, etc. It is believed that
one's birthday is suited to each other or not, esp. in marriage, because
of the said animal.
\gloss birth-day
\pl nMpUkJnq
\pd nAm1 pU2 kvn2
\pde the animals of one's birthday is favourable to each other
\example_phake nMfkqkJnq
\example_banchob nAm1 phAk3 kvn2
\example_english the animals of one's birthday is unfavourable
\dt 04/Mar/2015

\hm 1
\pos n
\sense 1

\lexeme palugqAannqta
\ph pA2 loN6 A2 nan2 tA2
\hm 1
\pos n.
\sense 1
\definition the fabulous fish which Tai people believe that it supports the earth.
Whenever it moves the body, it will cause an earthquake.
 During the earthquake, the Tai Phake will exclaim,
"<banchob kon2 mzN2 kAN2 yaN2 kqi4 z1>"
(oh! There are still people living on earth). ( Banchob )
\gloss fabulous.fish

\ph phI6 nam3
\pos n.
\definition the ancestor spirit of a family,  Tai Phake regarded as tutelary spirit,
the deitied soul of dead ancestors, it is represented by a  main post of the house in
the east side of the main bed room. The eldest member of
the house is to sleep near the post. The Tai Phakes belief
that it is a benevolent deity, so ancestors blessing are sought  for every major event of the
house.

day  every after eight days called
<waan2 kam2 > in honour of the deity. They sincerely refrain from tilling
soiling , seedling paddy, cutting tree, digging soil, and avoiding making of
high decible sound in the morning hours in these two days of  < wan kam > and
offer oblation twice in a year which falls on the second day of first wan

\example_english remember it please

\lexeme wnqkM
\ph wan2 kam2
\hm 1
\pos n
\sense 1
\definition a special and restricted day, observed by Tai Phake people in honour of < cau3 sz6 >
(ancestor spirit who looks after the Tai Phake village and Tai Phake people). Nobody works
before 11 a.m. on that day. It has two days in every after eight days as calculated by them
\gloss special restricted day
\se wnqkMeka
\ph wan2 kam2 kQ1
\pos n.
\definition the first day of < wan2 kam2 > restricted day
\gloss first day of restricted day
\se wnqkMstq
\ph wan2 kam2 sAt3
\pos n.
\definition the last day of< wan2 kam2 > restricted day
\gloss last day of restricted day
\dt 29/Jul/2014

\lexeme wnqxj
\ph wAn1 khai1
\hm 1
\pos n.
\sense 1
\definition offering of < wAn1 khai1 >  by the bride groom family to the head of the family of bride at the time of ritual of the wedding
ceremony is a customary system of Tai Phake and hence is inevitable. Its content 4 unboiled eggs in one bowl
and 4 or more unboiled eggs in another bowl covered with fine cloth. the unboil egg bowl is for
offering to house spirits and the unboiled is for distribution to the close relatives
\gloss bowls contents. unboil and boiled eggs
\dt 29/Jul/2014

\sense 1
\definition anything round or spherical
\gloss round.object
\pl huNqta
\pd hoi1 tA2
\pde an eye ball, an eye
\example_phake huNqlY igq
\example_banchob hoi1 laiN6
\example_english a wheel
\sense 2
\se huNq
\ph hoi1
\pos n

\gloss CLF.-round.things
\pl mkqsMhuNq
\pd mAk1 sAm6 hoi1
\pde 3 fruits
\example_phake houNqhinqsMhuNq
\example_banchob hoi1 hin6 sAm6 hoi1
\example_english three pieces stones

\lexeme Aitq

\lexeme Aitq
\ph et1
\hm 1
\pos n.
\sense 1
\definition one, in Tai Phake "et" is used as cardinal number, or compound numerals only in
sip et, ( eleven ) sAu2 et1 ( twenty one ) sAm6 sip1 et1 ( thirty one ) in stead of nVN2 ( one )  ( the "one" of
one hundred one or one thousand one or such are not used et )
\gloss one
\pl nJnqsipqAitq
\pd nzn2 sip1 et1
\pde the eleventh moth of the Tai calender year
\example_phake hY igqnJgqpjpkqsipqAitq
\example_banchob haiN6 nvN5 pAi2 pAk1 sip1 et1
\example_english one thousand one hundred eleven
